Very difficult to find information
No information could be found on this dam. Searched Google, Google Scholar, and 1search, Found one thing about a dam called three rivers in China but the construction date was wrong so it can't be.

The World bank in the cited text discusses 42,000 resettlers, and 19,000 further impacted in a negative economic way, which leads to 62,000; Could find any information about socioecomic impact/ analyses. Hydro-electtric dam. In 1992 built the Yantan Reservoir. It was found to have been the most important cause of the decrease in sediment flux in the Pearl River. Lots of documents expressing ecological concern: Sediment.

It was very difficult to find any information for this dam. The OSU Library Database has articles on seismic activity due to the reservoir. More credible and reliable information can be found in Chinese.

properties.NOTES: Additional displaced population estimates: 1900000 people; 13000000 people. Largest hydroelectric dam in the world.
properties.Benefits and Functions: Flood protectionFlood Control, Hydropower Generation and Transportation
properties.ECOL_IMPACTS: Altered downstream sediment transport significantly. Reduction in commercial harvest from 3.36 million tonnes in 2002 to 1.01 and 1.68 million tonnes respectively in 2004 and 2005. Threatens major fisheries in Yangtze River, including sturgeon and paddlefish, will change ecology of upstream reservoir. Hydrology: silt buildup upstream, erosion downstream, leading to salt water intrusion at mouth of Shanghai estuary. Hazards: landslides, reservoir-induced seismicity, possible bogs of exposed effluent posing health risk. Social: resettlement has been controversial, inadequate, plagued with corruption. Economic: spiralling costs to deal with water quality, resettlement, hazard mitigation. 388600 acres of land submerged.
properties.DISTRICT\/COUNTY: Hubei Province, Yichang City, Dianjun District
properties.OWNER: China Three Gorges Corporation

properties.NOTES: According to the Commission of large dams, 139 522 people have been resettled after the Zhexi construction. no informations were found regarding the other variables because all the article found were in chinese

0.8~0.82 mu (equals 0.048~0.049 hectare) arable land per person

residents were educated before relocated

properties.NOTES: EIA: minimal EIA for the Ahai dam was release to the public in Nov 2007. At least 3 protected fish species will be impacted. Scenic gorge would be inundated. Comments made on the EIA by International Rivers and Chinese NGOs have not been addressed. Cultural: project would inundate well preserved historic villages and farmland; could damage Baoshan Village, a 1000 year old Naxi village. Hazards: on May 30, 2007, the Yunnan Provincial People's Government issued a public announcement to stop dam construction until effective measures to protect shores and resettled peoples were created, after landslides collapsed the shoreline. Legal: approved in 2011. Additionally major preliminary work on the dam began prior to completion of an environmental impact assessment, a violation of the 2002 environmental impact law.

properties.OWNER: Yunnan Jinsha  River Hydropower Co., Ltd

properties.NOTES: Ecology: downstream impacts to fisheries, erosion, far-reaching impacts for lower SE Asian countries. Social: lack of adequate compensation, problems with food security and increased incidence of disease. Inconsistency in dam height between this spreadsheet and the Major Dams China Wikipedia spreadsheet (111 m). Other estimates for expected migrants is 6052
properties.ECOL_IMPACTS: 9806 acres of land submerged. The cumulative effect of dams on the Mekong includes an increase in the water level of the Tonle Sap Lake would result in a massive die-off of terrestrial vegetation. The cumulative effect of dams on the Mekong includes an increase in water level of 28-70 cm during dry season at junction of Tonle Sap and Mekong rivers and corresponding increase of 63 cm in Tonle Sap lake.  The 20 year forecast concludes a singificantly negative effect on the water level during wet season. Dams act as sediment traps that have a significant impact on sediment load of the Mekong.
properties.OWNER: SDIC Yunnan Dachaoshan Hydropower Co.,

This dam is part of the UN's Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) Program. Sinohydro is the builder.

properties.FINANCE_INST: GMS Power (Thai), Yunnan Electric Power Group Corporation, Yunnan Development and Investment Company
properties.MINORITY\/VULNERABLE: the Dai nationality
properties.NOTES: Ecology: project cuts through Xishuangbanna national reserve. Huaneng working with Kate Lazarus and WWF to trial HSAP. Other estimates for expected migrants is 2264.
properties.ECOL_IMPACTS: 6003 acres of land submerged. The cumulative effect of dams on the Mekong includes an increase in the water level of the Tonle Sap Lake would result in a massive die-off of terrestrial vegetation. The cumulative effect of dams on the Mekong includes an increase in water level of 28-70 cm during dry season at junction of Tonle Sap and Mekong rivers and corresponding increase of 63 cm in Tonle Sap lake.  The 20 year forecast concludes a singificantly negative effect on the water level during wet season.Dams act as sediment traps that have a significant impact on sediment load of the Mekong.
properties.OWNER: China Huaneng Lancang River Hydropower Company

properties.MINORITY\/VULNERABLE: Nu nationality, Tibetan nationality, Lisu nationality

The cumulative effect of dams on the Mekong includes an increase in the water level of the Tonle Sap Lake would result in a massive die-off of terrestrial vegetation. The cumulative effect of dams on the Mekong includes an increase in water level of 28-70 cm during dry season at junction of Tonle Sap and Mekong rivers and corresponding increase of 63 cm in Tonle Sap lake.  The 20 year forecast concludes a singificantly negative effect on the water level during wet season. Dams act as sediment traps that have a significant impact on sediment load of the Mekong.

properties.NOTES: Miaowei's project EIA was passed in March 2012 and the construction will finish in 2016. By 2015, all resettled communities have to move out of the area. There are also a few nonferrous metal mines in the region. Sinohydro is the builder

properties.NOTES: In an article dated May 28, 2009, International Probe cited a UN Report from May 21 of that year that stated that Xiaowan Dam alone is capable of reducing the water volume and running speed, lowering water quality and biodiversity of areas downstream on Lancang/Mekong River.   Other estimates for expected migrants is 32737
